ruleset.name: Security
ruleset.description: These rules deal with different security problems that can occur within Apex.

rule.name: ApexSharingViolations
rule.message: Apex classes should declare a sharing model if DML or SOQL/SOSL is used
rule.description: Detect classes declared without explicit sharing mode if DML methods are used. This forces the developer to take access restrictions into account before modifying objects.

rule.name: ApexOpenRedirect
rule.message: Apex classes should safely redirect to a known location
rule.description: Checks against redirects to user-controlled locations. This prevents attackers from redirecting users to phishing sites.

rule.name: ApexInsecureEndpoint
rule.message: Apex callouts should use encrypted communication channels
rule.description: Checks against accessing endpoints under plain **http**. You should always use **https** for security.

rule.name: ApexXSSFromURLParam
rule.message: Apex classes should escape/sanitize Strings obtained from URL parameters
rule.description: Makes sure that all values obtained from URL parameters are properly escaped / sanitized to avoid XSS attacks.

rule.name: ApexXSSFromEscapeFalse
rule.message: Apex classes should escape Strings in error messages
rule.description: Reports on calls to `addError` with disabled escaping. The message passed to `addError` will be displayed directly to the user in the UI, making it prime ground for XSS attacks if unescaped.

rule.name: ApexBadCrypto
rule.message: Apex classes should use random IV/key
rule.description: The rule makes sure you are using randomly generated IVs and keys for `Crypto` calls. Hard-wiring these values greatly compromises the security of encrypted data.

rule.name: ApexCSRF
rule.message: Avoid making DML operations in Apex class constructor/init method
rule.description: Check to avoid making DML operations in Apex class constructor/init method. This prevents modification of the database just by accessing a page.

rule.name: ApexSOQLInjection
rule.message: Avoid untrusted/unescaped variables in DML query
rule.description: Detects the usage of untrusted / unescaped variables in DML queries.

rule.name: ApexCRUDViolation
rule.message: Validate CRUD permission before SOQL/DML operation
rule.description: The rule validates you are checking for access permissions before a SOQL/SOSL/DML operation. Since Apex runs in system mode not having proper permissions checks results in escalation of privilege and may produce runtime errors. This check forces you to handle such scenarios.

rule.name: ApexDangerousMethods
rule.description:
Checks against calling dangerous methods.
For the time being, it reports:
* Against `FinancialForce`'s `Configuration.disableTriggerCRUDSecurity()`. Disabling CRUD security opens the door to several attacks and requires manual validation, which is unreliable. * Calling `System.debug` passing sensitive data as parameter, which could lead to exposure of private data.

rule.name: ApexSuggestUsingNamedCred
rule.description:
Detects hardcoded credentials used in requests to an endpoint.
You should refrain from hardcoding credentials: * They are hard to mantain by being mixed in application code * Particularly hard to update them when used from different classes * Granting a developer access to the codebase means granting knowledge of credentials, keeping a two-level access is not possible. * Using different credentials for different environments is troublesome and error-prone.
Instead, you should use *Named Credentials* and a callout endpoint.
For more information, you can check [this](https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.apexcode.meta/apexcode/apex_callouts_named_credentials.htm)
